description.narrative: AWYAD effort is to enhance protection of refugees through peaceful co-existence between the host communities and refugees in areas affected by the influx in Acholi sub-region. AWYAD is working with the local government authorities of Acholi sub-region to build confidence among the people and lobby the central government for increased resources to strengthen service delivery that copes with the refugee influx across the entire region. Such efforts will enhance the medium to long-term sustainability efforts within the response in Lamwo. AWYAD Project objective: To enhance harmonized, coherent and well-coordinated protection support for asylum seekers,refugees and host communities through strengthening the capacity of local governments and community leadership structures in Acholisub region. Key Project outcomes: (i) Strengthened capacity of host community leadership structures, local governments in particular in responding to safety and protection needs of the refugees and host communities. (ii) Commitment by donor agencies to allocate more funding for protection in humanitarian response work (iii) Mechanisms to address urban and community based refugees# protection and safety concerns are put in place in line with the existing policies and laws. (iv) Peaceful co-existence between refugees and host community embraced by informal and formal leadership structures. The proposed interventions by AWYAD will directly benefit 606 local leaders and stakeholders of which 242 females and 364 males. Indirectly, a total of 15,000 individuals will be reached by the targeted leaders. (i) Strengthened capacity of host community leadership structures, local governments in particular in responding tosafety and protection needs of the refugees and host communities. (ii) Commitment by donor agencies to allocate more funding for protection in humanitarian response work (iii) Mechanisms to address urban and community based refugees# protection and safety concerns are put in place in line with the existing policies and laws. (iv) Peaceful co-existence between refugees and host community embraced by informal and formal leadership structures. The proposed interventions by AWYAD will directly benefit 606 local leaders and stakeholders of which 242 females and 364 males. Indirectly, a total of 15,000 individuals will be reached by the targeted leaders.

participating-org.narrative: African Women and Youth Action for Development (AWYAD) is a Non-Government Organization (NGO) founded by Christians with a deep concern for vulnerable youth and women in Uganda, South Sudan, Kenya and Tanzania in the East African Region, living in abjectpoverty and whose voices cannot be heard. AWYAD was established 2010, by Christians with a passion to support vulnerable youth and women groups in various parts of the region, where 78% of youth are enslaved in the war of want, unintended self-torture, unproductiveness, crime, hunger and stress due to poverty as a result of joblessness and hopelessness. Over 70% of women in many rural communities live through untold suffering caused by horror of poverty associated with cultural and economic injustices such as discrimination and unpaid labour which is both on and off farm. During emergencies like sever famine and hunger and displacement, women and children suffer most from the consequences of the disaster. In order to overcome these challenges, AWYAD isdriven with a passion to work and advocate for change that eradicates the causes of poverty, discrimination and injustice striving to achieve equality, voice and empowerment. The organization targets vulnerable youth between the age of 15 <(>&<)> 30 years andvulnerable women including young single mothers, widows, women with HIV and disability with competitive skills and knowledge on agro business, promoting talent, innovation andentrepreneurship as well as nurturing and mentoring youth and women leaders withskills to influence, participate in decision makingfor the development of their families, their communities and nation.
